revision.comment: Alter: isbn, url, volume, pages. Add: issue, doi. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[User:Headbomb|Headbomb]]
revision.text:
{{Politics}} The combination of '''politics and technology''' covers concepts, mechanisms, personalities, efforts, and [[social movement]]s including but not necessarily limited to the [[Internet]] and other [[Information technology|information and communication technologies]] (ICTs). A growing body of scholarship has begun to explore how Internet technologies are influencing [[political communication]] and [[Participation (decision making)|participation]], especially in terms of what is known as the [[public sphere]]. One of the most influential and transformational information and communication technologies is the [[mobile phone]] or [[smartphone]], which can include: talk, text messaging, [[Internet]] and [[World Wide Web|Web]] access, [[electronic mail]], [[faxing]], pictures, video, and a wide variety of [[Mobile app|apps]]. Mobile devices are proving to increase political participation and are now even being portrayed as a voting gadget in even the [[least developed countries]]. Increased availability of this [[technology]] and subsequent access to the public sphere has enhanced the ability of individuals and groups to bring attention to and organize around specialized issues.Creeber, Glen. Digital Cultures: [understanding New Media]. Maidenhead: Open Univ., 2009. Print. More recently, [[social media]] has emerged to become one of the main areas of influence for [[politics]], where millions of users are able to learn about politicians' policies and statements, interact with political leaders, organize, and voice their own opinions on political matters.{{cite book|title=Politics and the Twitter revolution : how tweets influence the relationship between political leaders and the public|last2=Bichard|first2=Shannon|date=2012|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=9780739165010|location=Lanham, MD|page=1|pages=|last1=Parmelee|first1=John}} == The digital public sphere == The idea of the [[public sphere]] has generally come to be understood as the open social spaces and [[public space]]s in which private citizens interact and share information and ideas relevant to the society. These can include, for example, town halls, public squares, markets, coffee shops, or what ancient Greeks called [[agora]]s. Many scholars have argued that these spaces are vitally important for creating and maintaining an active and informed public in a democratic society.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/24669015|title=Free spaces : the sources of democratic change in America|last=Evans|first=Sara M.|last2=Boyte|first2=Harry C.|date=1992|publisher=University of Chicago Press|others=|year=|isbn=978-0226222578|edition= 2nd|location=Chicago|pages=|oclc=24669015}} In [[Jürgen Habermas]]' book ''[[The Structural Transformation of the Public Sphere|The Structural Transformation of the Public Sphere – An Inquiry into a Category of Bourgeois Society]]'', he defines the public sphere as "a realm of social life in which public opinion can be formed."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/18327374|title=The structural transformation of the public sphere : an inquiry into a category of bourgeois society|last=Jürgen|first=Habermas|publisher=|year=1962|isbn=978-0262081801|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=|oclc=18327374}} In principle, the public sphere should be open to all citizens, and free from influence from governments or private businesses. Habermas goes on to argue that:
"A portion of the public sphere is constituted in every conversation in which private persons come together to form a public. They are then acting neither as business or professional people conducting their private affairs, nor as legal consociates subject to the legal regulations of a state bureaucracy and obligated to obedience. Citizens act as a public when they deal with matters of general interest without being subject to coercion; thus with the guarantee that they may assemble and unite freely, and express and publicize their opinions freely."
[[Howard Rheingold]] argues that, "There is an intimate connection between informal conversations, the kind that take place in communities... and the ability of large social groups to govern themselves without monarchs or dictators.”{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/44162557|title=The virtual community : homesteading on the electronic frontier|last=Howard.|first=Rheingold,|date=2000|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=978-0262681216|edition= Rev. |location=Cambridge, Mass.|oclc=44162557}} Rheingold and others{{Cite journal|last=Dahlgren|first=Peter|date=2006|title=The Internet, Public Spheres, and Political Communication: Dispersion and Deliberation|journal=Political Communication|volume=22|issue=2|pages=147–162|doi=10.1080/10584600590933160}} have also gone on to argue that virtual spaces created through the [[Internet]] and related [[Information and communications technology|information and communications technologies]] have led to the emergence of a new type of digital public sphere. Some scholars have conceptualized this alternately as a virtual public sphere{{Cite journal|last=Papacharissi|first=Zizi|date=2002|title=The virtual sphere|journal=New Media & Society|language=en|volume=4|issue=1|pages=9–27|doi=10.1177/14614440222226244|issn=1461-4448}} or a networked public sphere,{{Cite journal|last=Shirky|first=Clay|date=2011|title=The Political Power of Social Media: Technology, the Public Sphere, and Political Change|jstor=25800379|journal=Foreign Affairs|volume=90|issue=1|pages=28–41}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/961312425|title=Twitter and tear gas : the power and fragility of networked protest|last=Zeynep|first=Tufekci|publisher=|year=2017|isbn=9780300215120|location=New Haven|pages=|oclc=961312425}} while still others have similarly described what they call a networked society{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/855022865|title=Communication power|last=Castells|first=Manuel|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2013|isbn=9780191510434|edition= 2nd|location=Oxford|pages=|oclc=855022865}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/795757037|title=Networks of outrage and hope: social movements in the Internet age|last=Castells|first=Manuel|date=|publisher=Polity|year=2015|isbn=9780745662855|edition= 2nd|location=Cambridge|pages=|oclc=795757037}} or networked publics.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/283798198|title=Networked Publics|last=Varnelis|first=Kazys|date=|publisher=MIT Press|others=Annenberg Center for Communication (University of Southern California)|year=2008|isbn=9780262285483|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=|oclc=283798198}} Essentially, these new virtual spaces can be used in much the same way as traditional, offline spaces; that is, as a "free space"{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/48943689|title=Democratic phoenix : reinventing political activism|last=Pippa|first=Norris|date=2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=978-0521811774|location=Cambridge, UK|pages=|oclc=48943689}} to discuss and debate ideas of public importance. Just as the public sphere is a combination of "every conversation in which private persons come together to form a public" the digital public sphere also comprises all forms of [[new media]], such as [[chat room]]s, website comment sections, and [[social media]], in which private citizens engage in discourse as a public. Virtual spaces may overlap or interact with offline spaces as well, forming what has been called "hybrid networks".{{Cite journal|last=Lim|first=Merlyna|date=2015|title=A CyberUrban Space Odyssey: The Spatiality of Contemporary Social Movements|url=https://www.academia.edu/16240525|journal=New Geographies|language=en|volume=7|pages=117–123|via=}} Many scholars argue that social media affords increasing opportunities for political discourse and mobilization within the digital public sphere.{{Cite journal|last=Loader|first=Brian D.|last2=Mercea|first2=Dan|date=2011|title=Networking Democracy? Social media innovations and participatory politics|journal=Information, Communication & Society|volume=14|issue=6|pages=757–769|doi=10.1080/1369118X.2011.592648}} Research has shown that increased use of social media correlates with increases in certain types of political engagement and [[Participation (decision making)|participation]].{{Cite journal|last=Boulianne|first=Shelly|date=|year=2015|title=Social media use and participation: a meta-analysis of current research|journal=Information, Communication & Society|volume=18|issue=5|pages=524–538|doi=10.1080/1369118X.2015.1008542}}{{Cite journal|last=Kahne|first=Joseph|last2=Bowyer|first2=Benjamin|date=2018|title=The Political Significance of Social Media Activity and Social Networks|journal=Political Communication|volume=35|issue=3|pages=470-493|doi=10.1080/10584609.2018.1426662}} The digital public sphere thus has the potential to enliven democratic culture{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/227016731|title=Viral spiral : how the commoners built a digital republic of their own|last=David.|first=Bollier,|date=2008|publisher=New Press|isbn=978-1595583963|location=New York|oclc=227016731}} and enhance the ability of citizens to challenge the political and economic power of governments and corporations such as through online [[protest]]s, [[activism]] campaigns, and [[social movement]]s.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/639573767|title=Digitally enabled social change : activism in the Internet age|last=Earl|first=Jennifer|last2=Kimport|first2=Katrina|date=|publisher=MIT Press|others=|year=2011|isbn=9780262015103|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=|oclc=639573767}} Other scholars have also highlighted, alongside [[economic globalization]], the role of Internet technologies to reach across national borders to contribute to a growing transnational public sphere.{{Cite book|url=http://www.press.umich.edu/11707|title=Globalizations and Social Movements|date=2000|publisher=University of Michigan Press|isbn=9780472097210|editor-last=Guidry|editor-first=John|location=Ann Arbor, MI|language=en|doi=10.3998/mpub.11707|editor-last2=Kennedy|editor-first2=Michael|editor-last3=Zald|editor-first3=Mayer}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/51817597|title=Transnational activism in Asia : problems of power and democracy|last=Piper|first=Nicola|last2=Uhlin|first2=Anders|date=|publisher=Routledge|others=|year=2004|isbn=978-0415315135|location=London|pages=|oclc=51817597}} === Criticisms === ==== Social exclusion ==== The traditional, offline public sphere has been criticized for not being as inclusive in practice as it is in theory.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/23650367|title=Habermas and the public sphere|last=|first=|publisher=MIT Press|others=|year=1992|isbn=978-0262031837|editor-last=Calhoun|editor-first=Craig J.|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=|oclc=23650367}} For example, Feminist scholars like [[Nancy Fraser]] have argued that the public sphere has historically not been as open or accessible to [[Social exclusion|disadvantaged or marginalized groups]] in a society, such as women or people of color; therefore, such groups are forced to form their own separate public spheres, which she refers to as a [[Counterpublic|counter-public]] or ''subaltern counter public''.{{Cite journal|last=Fraser|first=Nancy|date=1990|title=Rethinking the Public Sphere: A Contribution to the Critique of Actually Existing Democracy|jstor=466240|journal=Social Text|issue=25/26|pages=56–80|doi=10.2307/466240}} Some scholars contend that online spaces are more open and thus may help to increase inclusive political participation from marginalized groups.{{Cite journal|last=Schlosberg|first=David|last2=Dryzek|first2=John S.|date=2002|title=Digital Democracy: Authentic or Virtual?|jstor=26162195|journal=Organization & Environment|volume=15|issue=3|pages=332–335}} In particular, [[Anonymity|anonymous]] online spaces should allow all individuals to speak with an equal voice to others.{{Cite journal|last=Deseriis|first=M.|date=2013|title=Is Anonymous a New Form of Luddism?: A Comparative Analysis of Industrial Machine Breaking, Computer Hacking, and Related Rhetorical Strategies|journal=Radical History Review|language=en|volume=2013|issue=117|pages=33–48|doi=10.1215/01636545-2210437|issn=0163-6545}} However, other have pointed out that many contemporary online spaces are not anonymous, such as [[Facebook]]. Avatars and social media profiles often portray an individual's offline identity, which can lead to practices of online discrimination and exclusion which mirror offline inequalities.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/214085023|title=Digitizing race : visual cultures of the Internet|last=Lisa|first=Nakamura|date=2008|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|year=|isbn=9780816653775|location=Minneapolis|pages=|oclc=214085023}} Now, more and more historically disadvantaged or marginalized groups are also using Internet technology to carve out new online spaces for their own "networked counterpublics" such as through the use of [[hashtag]]s like #Ferguson and [[Black Lives Matter|#BlackLivesMatter]].{{Cite journal|last=Jackson|first=Sarah J.|last2=Foucault Welles|first2=Brooke|date=2015|title=Hijacking #myNYPD: Social Media Dissent and Networked Counterpublics|journal=Journal of Communication|language=en|volume=65|issue=6|pages=932–952|doi=10.1111/jcom.12185|issn=0021-9916}}{{Cite journal|last=Jackson|first=Sarah J.|last2=Foucault Welles|first2=Brooke|date=2016|title=#Ferguson is everywhere: initiators in emerging counterpublic networks|journal=Information, Communication & Society|volume=19|issue=3|pages=397–418|doi=10.1080/1369118X.2015.1106571}} ==== The digital divide ==== Another factor which affects access to the digital public sphere is the [[digital divide]], which refers to how people from [[Least Developed Countries|less developed countries]] tend to have less access to [[Information and communications technology|information and communications technologies]] compared to those from more [[Developed country|developed countries]]. For example, the most developed regions of the world, such as North America and Western Europe, have the highest [[Global Internet usage|Internet penetration rates]] at over 80% each, while the least developed countries such as in Africa and South Asia have less than 30% each.{{Cite web|url=https://www.statista.com/statistics/269329/penetration-rate-of-the-internet-by-region/|title=Global regional internet penetration rate 2017 {{!}} Statistic|website=Statista|language=en|access-date=2018-07-01}} On the other hand, the reduced cost and increasing availability of mobile devices such as [[smartphone]]s throughout less developed regions is helping to reduce this disparity at an exponential rate. In just two years, between 2013 and 2015, the number of Internet users in developing nations has risen by 9%, according to the [[Pew Research Center]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.pewglobal.org/2016/02/22/smartphone-ownership-and-internet-usage-continues-to-climb-in-emerging-economies/|title=Smartphone Ownership and Internet Usage Continues to Climb in Emerging Economies|date=2016-02-22|work=Pew Research Center's Global Attitudes Project|access-date=2018-07-01|language=en-US}} Other research has shown, though, that even within more developed countries like the United States, the digital divide continues to persist between upper and lower socioeconomic classes{{Cite news|url=https://www.brookings.edu/research/broadband-adoption-rates-and-gaps-in-u-s-metropolitan-areas/|title=Broadband adoption rates and gaps in U.S. metropolitan areas|last=Tomer|first=Adie|date=2015|work=Brookings|access-date=2018-07-01|last2=Kane|first2=Jospeh|language=en-US}} and between different education levels.{{Cite news|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2018/03/05/some-americans-dont-use-the-internet-who-are-they/|title=11% of Americans don’t use the internet. Who are they?|date=2018-03-05|work=Pew Research Center|access-date=2018-07-01|language=en-US}} Furthermore, scholars like [[Mark Warschauer]] argue that it is not just access to technology that matters, but the knowledge of how to put that technology to use in meaningful ways.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/50028800|title=Technology and social inclusion : rethinking the digital divide|last=Mark.|first=Warschauer,|date=2003|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=978-0262232241|location=Cambridge, Mass.|oclc=50028800}} == See also == * [[Cultural lag]] *[[Online deliberation]] * [[Media activism]] *[[Hashtag activism]] * [[Internet activism]] * [[Digital rights|Digital Rights]] * [[Netizen]] * [[Internet censorship]] * [[Neo-Luddism]] * [[Technocracy]] *[[Public hypersphere]] * [[Technology policy]] * [[E-democracy]] * [[E-government]] *[[Electronic voting]] * [[:Category:Regulation of technologies]] == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Politics by issue|Technology]] [[Category:Technology in society]] [[Category:Politics and technology| ]]

'''Prostitution in Denmark''' was partly decriminalized in 1999, based partly on the premise that it was easier to police a legal trade than an illegal one. Third-party activities, such as profiting from [[brothel]] administration and other forms of [[procuring (prostitution)|procuring]], remain illegal activities in [[Denmark]], as do [[pimp]]ing and [[prostitution]] of minors.{{Cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2007/100556.htm |title=Country Reports on Human Rights 2007: Denmark |publisher=US State Department |date=2008-03-11 |accessdate=2010-03-31}}{{Cite news|url=http://thecnnfreedomproject.blogs.cnn.com/2011/03/30/sex-trafficking-countries-take-different-approaches-to-same-problem/|title=The battle against sex trafficking: Sweden vs. Denmark |publisher=CNN|date=2011-03-30 |accessdate=2012-05-30}} == History == === Early period === Prostitution ("professional [[fornication]]") was regulated in Denmark during the nineteenth century, with police playing an active part, particularly after 1864, and even forcing women to register at [[brothels]]. Technically prostitution was illegal, so regulation was carried out discreetly by order of [[King Frederick VI]] (1808-1839), Danish law prescribed jail for men and whipping for women caught in fornication. Nineteenth-century policies to prostitution were driven by the idea that it was a primary source for [[sexually transmitted diseases]], with women being subject to increasingly regular examinations. As in other countries women could be forcefully hospitalized after registration was introduced in 1815. During the century rules and practice were progressively tightened. These policies became the target of women's groups and religious groups forcing some relaxation in 1885. Brothels were eventually banned in 1901 and in 1906 forceful examination was abandoned. === Modern era === Decriminalization occurred in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://sciencenordic.com/police-forced-prostitutes-brothels|title=Police forced prostitutes into brothels|publisher=}} In 2006, the government announced a campaign to combat prostitution and racketeers involved in organizing the trade and [[human trafficking]], following a commissioned police report entitled ''Strategi for en styrket politimæssig indsats mod prostitutionens bagmænd''. Justice Minister [[Lene Espersen]] (DFK) announced an intensified police effort against traffickers while promising a more sympathetic approach to victims and witnesses, with new police reforms effective 1 January 2007. This would replace an earlier strategy due to expire at the end of 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.justitsministeriet.dk/nyt-og-presse/pressemeddelelser/2006/styrket-indsats-mod-prostitutionens-bagm%C3%A6nd|title=Styrket indsats mod prostitutionens bagmænd - Justitsministeriet|website=www.justitsministeriet.dk}} In February 2013, Justice Minister [[Morten Bødskov]] announced further measures and introduced a bill, arising from the 2012 report of the Criminal law Council, extending provisions against exploitation from brothels to escort services and street prostitution, increasing penalties and giving police more powers.{{cite web|url=http://www.justitsministeriet.dk/ministeren/ministerens-indl%C3%A6g/2013/regeringen-styrker-indsatsen-mod-prostitutionens-bagm%C3%A6nd|title=Regeringen styrker indsatsen mod prostitutionens bagmænd - Justitsministeriet|website=www.justitsministeriet.dk}} === Review 2012 === In 2009, the Ministry of Justice ordered the Criminal Code Council (''Straffelovrådet'') to undertake a comprehensive review of Chapter 24, and they delivered their report in November 2012.{{cite web|url=http://jm.schultzboghandel.dk/publikationer/publikationsdetaljer.aspx?PId=af97a338-6fd4-4042-92fb-b120a3d459f2|title=Justitsministeriet - Publikationer|website=jm.schultzboghandel.dk}} In the terms of reference, they were asked specifically to comment on whether the buying of sex should be banned. Amongst their recommendations were; * To introduce a new comprehensive provision for the involvement of a person under 18 years in prostitution * Eliminating special provisions for the participation of 18- to 20-year-olds in prostitution * That prostitution business in other forms than keeping a brothel be covered by including the provision of escort services * To decriminalize the involvement of third parties in prostitution, where the agent does not operate by exploiting the prostitution of others * The removal of the Penal Code provisions involving the request or invitation to fornication that arouses public indignation * To eliminate the possibility that a person is prevented from entering a particular restaurant for the sole reason that he or she works as a prostitute In addition, the Council proposed adjusting the maximum penalties for the participation of a child under 18, for payment or promise of payment, having sexual relations with a client, or for being a spectator to a show with pornographic performances involving a child under 18, in order to meet the demands of the EU directive on combating the sexual abuse of children. They also proposed adjusting the maximum penalties for aiding the prostitution of others. With regards to a ban on buying sex, the Council concluded that such a ban would only be justified as a moral rejection of the purchase of sex. With the knowledge on prostitution in Denmark and the information on the experience of the ban on buying sex in other countries, the Council's opinion was that a ban on buying sex will not have a significant positive impact in any other respects than the punishing those who purchase sex. On the contrary, a ban on buying sex could have negative consequences for a number of prostitutes in terms of worsening economic conditions and in the form of increased stigma. On receiving their report, the [[Justice Minister of Denmark|Minister of Justice]] (''Justitsministeren'') [[Morten Bødskov]] made these remarks: "The government has also decided to follow the Criminal Code Council recommendation not to impose a ban on buying sex (''købesex''). The Criminal Council study shows that a ban on buying sex is not likely to lead to a decrease in prostitution or the exploitation of prostitutes, but rather is likely to have negative consequences for the prostitutes." (21 November 2012)."Regeringen har desuden besluttet af følge Straffelovrådets anbefaling om ikke at indføre et forbud mod købesex. Straffelovrådets undersøgelse viser, at et forbud mod købesex ikke kan forventes at føre til at fald i prostitutionen eller i udnyttelsen af prostituerede, men tværtimod må forventes at have negative konsekvenser for de prostituerede." === Legal texts === '''§ 228'''
(1) Any person who- 1) induces another to seek a profit by sexual immorality with others; or 2) for the purpose of gain, induces another to indulge in sexual immorality with others or prevents another who engages in sexual immorality as a profession from giving it up; or 3) keeps a brothel; -shall be guilty of procuring and liable to imprisonment for any term not exceeding four years. (2) The same penalty shall apply to any person who incites or helps a person under the age of twenty-one (21) to engage in sexual immorality as a profession, or to any person who abets some other person to leave the Kingdom in order that the latter shall engage in sexual immorality as a profession abroad or shall be used for such immorality, where that person is under the age of twenty-one (21) or is at the time ignorant of the purpose. '''§ 229'''
(1) Any person who, for the purpose of gain or in frequently repeated cases, promotes sexual immorality by acting as an intermediary, or who derives profit from the activities of any person engaging in sexual immorality as a profession, shall be liable to imprisonment for any term not exceeding three years or, in mitigating circumstances, to simple detention or a fine. (2) Any person who lets a room in a hotel or an inn for the carrying on of prostitution as a profession shall be liable to simple detention or imprisonment for any term not exceeding one year or, in mitigating circumstances, to a fine. '''§ 233'''
Any person who incites or invites other persons to prostitution or exhibits immoral habits in a manner which is likely to annoy others or arouse public offence shall be liable to simple detention or to imprisonment for any term not exceeding one year or, in mitigating circumstances, to a fine. ==Demographics== The [[US State Department]] said that a 2008 report from the National Board of Social Services states that police estimate the number of persons involved in prostitution is approximately 5,500.{{Cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136028.htm|title=Country Reports on Human Rights 2009: Denmark |publisher=US State Department |date=2008-03-11 |accessdate=2011-02-23}} The traditional center for prostitution in [[Copenhagen]] is the district behind the [[Copenhagen Central Station|Copenhagen Central Rail Station]] (mainly [[Istedgade]], [[Halmtorvet]] and [[Skelbækgade]]). At the commencement of 2009, the number of street-based sex workers and sex-oriented businesses in the area was declining, but there appeared to be a growth in numbers by the middle of that same year.[http://www.cphpost.dk/news/national/88-national/46350-warnings-of-discount-prostitution-trend.html Warnings of discount prostitution trend] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110120152808/http://cphpost.dk/news/national/88-national/46350-warnings-of-discount-prostitution-trend.html |date=20 January 2011 }}. Copenhagen Post Wednesday, 22 July 2009 Most of the people entering the industry originated from Eastern Europe and Africa. Like many other European cities, many sex workers now use internet-based advertisements for [[incall]] and [[outcall]] services.{{cite web|last1=Andreou|first1=Aggelos|title=Selling sex in Aarhus|url=http://www.jutlandstation.dk/selling-sex-in-aarhus/|website=Jutland Station|accessdate=14 April 2018|date=23 November 2014}} ===Migration and sex trafficking=== {{see also|Human trafficking in Denmark}} A 2009 study by [[TAMPEP]] estimated that migrant workers make up 65% of all prostitutes in Denmark.[http://euobserver.com/9/29340 Romanian sex workers most prevalent in EU]. EU Observer 26 January 2010 However, the most recent report from the [[Servicestyrelsen]] agency states that about half of the sex workers in Denmark are migrants. The largest group, about 900, come from [[Thailand]] and, typically, these workers hold a [[Permanent residency|residence permit]] or Danish citizenship. The migrant workers are entitled to a wide range of social and health benefits, but are not always aware that such services exist for them. The next largest group, totaling about 1,000, are from [[European Union]] (EU) countries in Central and Eastern Europe, but tend to commute between Denmark and their homeland; such individuals are therefore not entitled to receive assistance from Danish [[Social work|social services]]. The third largest sex worker migrant group, from Africa (especially [[Nigeria]]), numbers around 300 and a number of the African migrants commute between other [[Schengen Area]] countries and Denmark. (A similar situation exists in [[Norway]].){{cite web|url=http://www.servicestyrelsen.dk/udgivelser/udsatte/prostitution/migrantprostitution-i-danmark-notat|title=Servicestrelsen: Migrantprostitution i Danmark 2011|publisher=}} A number of women from all three migrant groups may be victims of [[human trafficking]], the actual proportion is unknown, with no reliable figures detailing the number of trafficked persons currently available for analysis. In 2008 the police met with 431 women suspected of association with trafficking and 72 were confirmed to be victims. According to Copenhagen police, women are recruited in their native countries, transported to Denmark, and then forced into prostitution. ==Clients== A 2005 study of male clientele by Claus Lautrups found that 14% of Danish men have paid for sex at least once.[http://www.dagbladene.dk/index.php?mod=news&area=1&id=168 Jeg ligger i kø på motorvejen!] Dagbladenes Bureau 26 March 2009[http://www.redenkoebenhavn.dk/data/archive/Link/detskalikkebarevaereenkropmodkropoplevelse.pdf "Det skal ikke bare være en krop mod krop-oplevelse...": en sociologisk undersøgelse om prostitutionskunder. Af Claus Lautrup. VFC Socialt Udsatte, 2005. Undersøgelsesrapport.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719130745/http://www.redenkoebenhavn.dk/data/archive/Link/detskalikkebarevaereenkropmodkropoplevelse.pdf |date=19 July 2011 }}''"Af de 6.350 mænd, som deltager i spørgeskemaundersøgelsen, svarer 14 procent, at de har købt sex"'' == Political debates == The then-[[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Social Democrat]] (S) government of [[Poul Nyrup Rasmussen]] reformed the penal code on 17 March 1999, coming into force on 1 July 1999 to decriminalize prostitution. The Social Democrats lost power in 2001. As elsewhere in [[Scandinavia]], there has been a continuing debate about the status of prostitution laws. The then-opposition [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Social Democrats]] and feminist groups favoured outlawing the buying of sexual acts in 2009.[http://www.cphpost.dk/news/politics/90-politics/46107-new-government-could-ban-buying-sex.html New government could ban buying sex]. Copenhagen Post 29 June 2009 This would have put Denmark in line with [[Sweden]], [[Norway]], and [[Iceland]], Norway having adopted such legislation in 2009. This position was supported by a number of opposition parties, including the [[Enhedslisten|Red-Green Alliance]] (''Enhedslisten'', EL) and the [[Socialist People's Party (Denmark)|Socialist People's Party]] (SF), but not the [[Det Radikale Venstre|Social Liberals]] (R). This position had little popular support, only about 26% supporting the measure. (see '''[[#Public opinion|Public opinion]]'''). At that time, Denmark was governed by a [[centre-right]] [[minority government]] consisting of the [[Venstre (Denmark)|Liberal Party]] (''Venstre'', V) and the [[Conservative People's Party (Denmark)|Conservative People's Party]] (''Det Konservative Folkeparti'', DKF). In June 2011, responding to both an opinion poll and recent [[#Research|research]] (which see) the opposition [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Social Democrats]] (S), supported by the [[Socialist People's Party (Denmark)|Socialist People's Party]] (SF), were in favour of the [[Prostitution in Sweden|Swedish model]] of banning the sale of sex, and did not consider the issue of rights identified in the 2011 poll. This put them at odds with the minority governing parties, the [[Venstre (Denmark)|Liberals (Venstre)]] (V), although the position of the junior governing party, the [[Conservative People's Party (Denmark)|Conservatives]]'s (K), position was less clear. On the other hand, the opposition [[Danish People's Party|People's Party]] (DF) was more supportive of rights, looking to [[Prostitution in New Zealand|New Zealand]]. In Denmark's complex political mosaic, the [[Danish Social Liberal Party|Radicals (Social Liberals)]] (R), who were divided on the issue, were in a position of holding the balance of power on the issue. It was anticipated that if the Social Democrats were returned to power, they would follow Sweden's example. In the September 2011 elections, the centre-right coalition lost power to a [[centre-left]] coalition led by the Social Democrats, together with the Social Liberals and the [[Socialist People's Party (Denmark)|Socialist People's Party]] (''Socialistisk Folkeparti'', SF), and were in a position to change the laws. However, the Socialist People's Party withdrew from the coalition on 30 January 2014, [[Cabinet of Helle Thorning-Schmidt II|leaving the Social Democrats heavily dependent]] on the support of the opposition Venstre, and consequently having to modify their election promises, although the Socialist People's party continue to support the government. == Public opinion == A public opinion poll in 2011 showed that 61% of Danes think Danish sex workers should have more rights, and their profession recognized. Support was found by the majority of voters for all parties, but most noticeably for the relatively small [[Liberal Alliance (Denmark)|Liberal Alliance]] (LA). The question was: ''"In Denmark, prostitution is legal, and prostitutes are in principle taxable. Prostitution is not recognized as a profession, and the prostitutes are not able to join a union, receive benefits, or be eligible for employment insurance. Are you in favour or opposed to prostitutes being allowed to join a union in order to receive benefits and employment insurance?"''[http://www.altinget.dk/artikel/danskerne-vil-give-prostituerede-flere-rettigheder Danskerne vil give prostituerede flere rettigheder]. Altinget.dk 10 June 2011 == Research == In 2010, the Danish government, responding to criticisms that the debate on prostitution was largely based on myths and stereotypes, allocated DKK 4 million for a national survey by ''Det Nationale Forskningscenter for Velfærd'',{{cite web|url=http://www.sfi.dk|title=SFI- Det Nationale Forskningcenter for Velfærd|website=www.sfi.dk}} which was published in 2011 as ''Prostitution i Danmark''.[http://www.altinget.dk/misc/prostitution.pdf Prostitution i Danmark'] The report stressed that prostitution cannot be treated as a monolithic or homogeneous entity, in particular drawing a distinction between outdoor (street) and indoor work. It suggested a more targeted approach, pointing out that most sex workers had chosen their profession, rather than being coerced. ==Autonomous constituent countries== ===Faroe Islands=== Under [[Courts of Denmark|Danish Jurisdiction]], the legal status of prostitution remains lawful. However, there is no evidence of organised prostitution within the self-governing territory. ===Greenland=== Prostitution in [[Greenland]] is illegal.{{cite news|title=Small-Town Greenland Prepares for Influx of Foreign Workers|url=https://www.theepochtimes.com/small-town-greenland-prepares-for-influx-of-foreign-workers_1480624.html|author=Susanne Willgren|newspaper=The Epoch Times|date=31 October 2012|accessdate=28 October 2017}} Although the country is subject to the [[law of Denmark]] in most areas of legislation, Denmark's decriminalization of prostitution in 1999 has not been applied in Greenland.{{cite report|title=Prostitution in the Nordic Countries|url=http://norden.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2:701621/FULLTEXT01.pdf|location=Stockholm|date=16–17 October 2008|first1=Charlotta|last1=Holmström|first2=May-Len|last2=Skilbrei|publisher=Nordic Council of Ministers|isbn=978-92-893-1930-0}} In addition, Greenland is exempt from the obligations of the [[Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, especially Women and Children|Palermo Protocol on human trafficking]] to which Denmark is a signatory, but there is little evidence of human trafficking in Greenland.{{cite report|title=Human Trafficking as a Human Rights Issue And Policy Responses of Arctic Nations|url=https://www.rha.is/static/files/NRF/OpenAssemblies/Anchorage2008/a/5th_nrf_anc_2008_footen_bromfield_human_trafficking.pdf|first=Nicole Footen|last=Bromfield|publisher=Virginia Commonwealth University|page=10|accessdate=28 October 2017}} A report published in 2008 indicated that Greenland had no signs of visible or organised prostitution, no services directed specifically at prostitutes and no instances of prostitution-related court cases. It did, however, refer to claims that [[transactional sex]] had sometimes been used, for example, in return for temporary housing. In a tradition associated with Greenland's [[Inuit]] people, hosts have been reported to have offered their wives to guests in a form of "hospitable prostitution".{{cite book|title=Criminal Woman, the Prostitute, and the Normal Woman|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=S3g29DlTxNsC|first1=Cesare|last1=Lombroso|first2=Guglielmo|last2=Ferrero|publisher=Duke University Press|year=2004|isbn=9780822332466|page=101}} The colonists who founded the country's capital [[Nuuk]] in 1728 included prostitutes among their number.{{cite book|last1=Wurm|first1=Stephen A.|last2=Mühlhäusler|first2=Peter |last3=Tyron|first3=Darrell T.|title=Atlas of Languages of Intercultural Communication in the Pacific, Asia, and the Americas, International Council for Philosophy and Humanistic Studies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=glU0vte5gSkC|series=Volume 2, Part 1 Volume 13 of Trends in Linguistics|year=1996|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-013417-9|page=1051}} == See also == {{Portal|Denmark|European Union}} *[[Government of Denmark]] *[[Folketing|Folketing (Danish Parliament)]] *[[Cabinet of Denmark]] *[[Justice Minister of Denmark]] *[[Elections in Denmark]] *[[Politics of Denmark]] *[[List of political parties in Denmark]] *[[Outline of Denmark]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web|url=http://www.justitsministeriet.dk/nyt-og-presse/pressemeddelelser/2012/straffelovr%C3%A5det-foresl%C3%A5r-sk%C3%A6rpelser-over-seksualforbrydelser|title=Straffelovrådet foreslår skærpelser over for seksualforbrydelser - Justitsministeriet|website=www.justitsministeriet.dk}} }} == Notes == {{Reflist|group="nb"}} == Bibliography == === Nordic policies === * [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9781409444268 May-Len Skilbrei. Prostitution Policy in the Nordic Region. Ashgate 2013] {{ISBN|978-1-4094-4426-8}} * [http://theconversation.com/the-nordic-model-of-prostitution-law-is-a-myth-21351 May-Len Skilbrei and Charlotta Holmström. The ‘Nordic model’ of prostitution law is a myth. The Conversation 16 December 2013] * Skilbrei, May-Len & Charlotta Holmström (2013): Prostitution Policy in the Nordic Region. Ambiguous Sympathies, Farnham: Ashgate. === History=== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110721124553/http://www.historians.ie/women/Newsletter%20No%2036%20%20Denmark.htm Pedersen: Prostitution in Denmark 1860-1906. Int Fed Res Women’s Hist 2003] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110719121734/http://www.danmedbul.dk/Dmb_2006/0206/0206-phd/DMB3840.htm Merete Bøge Pedersen: Tempting outcasts. On common prostitutes in the 19th century. Bibliotek for Læger 2006;198:38-57] === Regulation === * [http://www.nikk.uio.no/?module=Articles;action=Article.publicShow;ID=891 Prostitution legislation: Will they go the same way? NIKK 19 March 2009] * [http://jm.schultzboghandel.dk/publikationer/publikationsdetaljer.aspx?PId=af97a338-6fd4-4042-92fb-b120a3d459f2 Straffelovrådets betænkning om seksualforbrydelser. Betænkning nr. 1534. November 2012] Criminal Code Council review of sexual offences 2012 === Migration === * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150714160224/http://tampep.eu/documents/TAMPEP%202009%20European%20Mapping%20Report.pdf Sex work in Europe - A mapping of the prostitution scene in 25 European countries TAMPEP 2009] * [http://www.nikk.no/?module=Articles;action=Article.publicShow;ID=507 Marlene Spanger. Between Suppression and Independence. Transnational Prostitution of Black Women in Denmark. NIKK 2002] * [http://sciencenordic.com/myths-about-prostitute-lifestyle Rasmus Karkov. Myths about the prostitute lifestyle. Science Nordic 19 August 2012] === Health === * [http://www.dnms.no/index.php?seks_id=121506&a=1 Ida Blom. Medicine and morality - legislation on venereal diseases in Denmark and Norway c. 1900-1994. Michael 2010;7:321-330] * [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16219218 Ishøy T, Ishøy PL, Olsen LR. Street prostitution and drug addiction. Ugeskrift for Lægerer. 2005 Sep 26;167(39):3692-6.] ''In Danish'' === Other === * [http://www.[[Humanity in Action]].org/docs/Armario__Dollner,_2002.pdf Armario and Dollner: Prostitution in Denmark. Humanity in Action 2002] * [http://www.kvinfo.dk/side/676/article/55/ Danish stance on prostitution. Kvinfo Dec. 2006] * [http://www.kvinfo.dk/side/674/article/111/ Prostitution of poverty or sexual self-determination? Kvinfo June 2010] * [http://projekter.aau.dk/projekter/da/studentthesis/approaching-prostitution-differences-need-not-be-barriers%28e14ec25c-d229-4f6a-8f8b-1336dee1a656%29.html Approaching Prostitution: Differences Need not be Barriers : An Analysis of Interdisciplinary Collaboration in Servicestyrelsen's Prostitution Department. Emily Childers-Brocks Masters Thesis Feb 2010, Aalborg] * [http://sciencenordic.com/what-drives-prostitute Rasmus Karkov. What drives a prostitute. Science Nordic 7 March 2012] == External links == === Government === * [http://www.justitsministeriet.dk/generelt/english Ministry of Justice] * [https://www.retsinformation.dk/Forms/R0710.aspx?id=142912 ''Straffeloven''] Penal Code ** [https://www.retsinformation.dk/Forms/R0710.aspx?id=142912#Kap24 Chapter 24: Forbrydelser mod kønssædeligheden] Sexual offences === Research === * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090310112719/http://www.nikk.no/English/ Nordic Gender Institute (NIKK)] * [http://nppr.se/ Nordic Prostitution Policy Reform] === Organizations === * [http://www.s-i-o.dk/?page_id=298 SIO - Danish sex worker organization] * [http://sexworkeurope.org/ ICRSE - European network of sex workers and allies] * [http://www.nswp.org/ Global Network of Sex Work Projects] * [http://www.nordicbaltic-assistwomen.net/spip.php?article14 The Nest-STOP Trafficking / Reden STOP-Kvindehandel] ''Support group for trafficking victims'' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110719131047/http://www.servicestyrelsen.dk/udsatte/prostitution Servicestyrelsen: Prostitution] ''Service Agency Prostitution Unit'' ** [http://www.servicestyrelsen.dk/udgivelser/udsatte/prostitution Publications] {{Europe in topic|Prostitution in}} {{Denmark topics}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Prostitution In Denmark}} [[Category:Prostitution by country|Denmark]] [[Category:Prostitution in Europe|Denmark]] [[Category:Danish society]] [[Category:Sex industry in Denmark]]

{{Use Indian English|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{infobox politician |name = |native_name = రసమయి బాలకిషన్ |image = |order1 = 1st |office1 = Chairman, Telangana Samskruthika Sarathi |term_start1 = 6 December 2015 |term_end1 = |predecessor1 = ''Office established'' |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|05|15|df=y}} |birth_place = Raorukula village, [[Siddipet]], [[Telangana]], India |residence = [[Hyderabad]], Telangana, India |spouse = Razia Sulthana |children = Amith
Adarsh |office2 = [[Member of the Legislative Assembly]] |term_start2 = 2014 |constituency2 = [[Manakondur]], Telangana State }} '''Rasamayi Balakishan''' ({{lang-te|రసమయి బాలకిషన్}}; born on 15 May 1965), is a [[Member of the Legislative Assembly]] (Telangana) from the [[Manakonduru constituency]] in [[Karimnagar District]] in Telangana.{{cite web|url=http://www.telangananewspaper.com/rasamayi-balakishan-profile-caste-home-songs/|title=MLA Rasamayi Balakishan Profile.|website=Telangananewspaper.com|accessdate=15 January 2018}} He is a [[singer]], [[poet]] and [[Political activism|political activist]]. He is also appointed as [[Chairman]] of State Cultural Council (Telangana Samskruthika Sarathi) with cabinet rank. He is the founder of Telangana Dhoom Dham.{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/telangana/Rasamayi-Balakishan-Named-TSS-Chairman/2014/12/06/article2558123.ece|title='Rasamayi' Balakishan Named TSS Chairman|website=Newindianexpress.com|accessdate=15 January 2018}} {{cite web|url=http://v6news.tv/trs-mla-rasamayi-balakishan-appointed-as-chairman-of-cultural-department|title=TRS MLA Rasamayi Balakishan appointed as Chairman of Cultural Department|date=30 January 2015|website=V6news.tv|accessdate=15 January 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-telangana/bhagiratha-water-by-jan-30-trials-to-start/article22389972.ece|title=Bhagiratha water by Jan. 30, trials to start|date=7 January 2018|accessdate=15 January 2018|website=Thehindu.com}} ==Early life== Born Erpula Balakishan, in Raorukula village in Siddipet Mandal, Andhra Pradesh to Rajaiah (d. 2010) and Maisamma (d. 2013). Both his parents were illiterate. His family was popular for their folk songs and sappy instrument. He came to be known by the folk song troupe, Rasmayi, became part of his name. He was appointed as the chairman of cultural Department.{{cite web|url=http://www.telanganastateofficial.com/rasamayi-balakishan-chairman-of-cultural-department/|title=Rasamayi BalaKishan Chairman of Cultural Department|date=5 December 2014|website=Telanganastateofficial.com|accessdate=15 January 2018}} He heads the cultural troupe for the formation of separate [[Telangana state]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/TRS-upbeat-on-lsquomaha-garjanarsquo/article15187208.ece|title=TRS upbeat on ‘maha garjana’|date=19 March 2008|accessdate=15 January 2018|website=Thehindu.com}} He is the convener of the Telangana Dhoom Dhaam Committee, one of the mini-cultural outfits of the statehood movement.[http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?264118] {{dead link|date=January 2018}} ==Career== In 1995, Rasamayi Balakishan started his career as a teacher and [[ballad]]eer. He was part of the cultural troupe of [[Telangana Rashtra Samithi|TRS party]]. He often engages the audience and entertains with his local folk songs and dance. He is widely performing at the [[Telangana]] movement events in 2009-10. ===Political career=== He entered politics by joining TRS party. He was elected as a MLA from TRS party from Manakondur constituency in Karimnagar in 2014 General Elections. He is highly respected for his oratorial skills in the state assembly, and actively participates in debates with the opposition. ==Personal ilfe== He is married to Razia Sultana. They have two sons, Amith and Adarsh. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Balakishan, Rasamayi}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Indian male folk singers]] [[Category:Telangana MLAs 2014–]] [[Category:Telugu people]] [[Category:People from Telangana]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:1965 births]]

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} The '''real estate sector in Kenya''' has seen a boom that began somewhere in the mid to late 2000s because the property market is responding to [[Economy of Kenya|increased demand]]. In [[Nairobi]], the capital and largest city of [[Kenya]], there is one of the largest expatriate communities in the continent due to the significant number of multinationals who have chosen Nairobi as either their African hub or East and Central African hub.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Opinion-and-Analysis/Why-Kenyan-real-estate-sector-is-robust-/-/539548/1909974/-/vf6wfz/-/index.html|title=Why Kenya’s real estate sector is robust|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2016}} The rebirth of property development in Nairobi has attracted global attention. In its 2012 Wealth Report, real estate management company, Knight Frank, ranked Nairobi as the fastest-growing real estate market in the world, outpacing cities like Miami and Monaco.{{cite web|title=Nairobi’s Changing Skyline: Commercial Real Estate On The Rise|url=http://abacus.co.ke/nairobis-changing-skyline-commercial-real-estate-on-the-rise/|website=http://abacus.co.ke/|publisher=Abacus|accessdate=11 September 2014}} Real estate prices in Nairobi rose 25 percent between January and December 2011. Nairobi was also voted as one of the top 10 cities to watch by global real estate firm, Jones Lang LaSalle, out of 150 cities globally.{{cite web|url=http://hayerone.com/real-estate-boom-in-kenya-2018/|title=Real Estate Market Boom In Kenya 2018|publisher=hayerone|accessdate=25 June 2018}} == Kenyan cities == {{See also|List of companies and organisations based in Nairobi#International Companies with African headquarters in Nairobi|l1=International companies and organisations based in Nairobi}} In 2012, [[Nairobi]] and [[Mombasa]] were the only cities in the "southern hemisphere" to have reported double digit property price increases, out of 71 cities surveyed in the Prime International Residential Index.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Nairobi-tops-global-cities-in-property-prices-rally/-/539552/1376198/-/ixqtsbz/-/index.html|title=Nairobi tops global cities in property prices rally|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2016}} The table shows property price growth in the top cities in the survey. {| class="wikitable" |- | width="20px" style="background-color:#90EE90" | | Kenya |} {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! City || Country ||Percentage increase between 2011 and 2012 (%) |-bgcolor="#90EE90" | [[Nairobi]] || {{flag|Kenya}}|| 25 |-bgcolor="#90EE90" | [[Mombasa]] || {{flag|Kenya}} || 20 |- | [[Miami]] || {{flag|USA}} || 19.1 |- | [[Bali]] || {{flag|Indonesia}} || 15 |- | [[Jakarta]] || {{flag|Indonesia}} || 14.3 |- | [[London]] || {{flag|United Kingdom}} || 12.1 |- | [[Vancouver]] || {{flag|Canada}}|| 10.4 |- | [[Moscow]] || {{flag|Russia}} || 9.8 |- | [[Toronto]] || {{flag|Canada}}|| 8.5 |- | [[Beijing]] || {{flag|China}} || 8.1 |- |} Source: [http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Nairobi-tops-global-cities-in-property-prices-rally/-/539552/1376198/-/ixqtsbz/-/index.html/ BusinessDaily] The report noted that inflows from Kenyans in the diaspora are particularly significant in driving the prices and that the cost per square metre of land in [[Nairobi]] and [[Mombasa]] is still lower than other cities such as [[Monaco]]. ==Markets== ===Office=== The office market in Kenya has moved from a position of oversupply and the market is finally stabilising, as Nairobi reinforces its position as the regional commercial hub of Sub-Saharan Africa.{{Cite web |url=http://resources.knightfrank.com/GetResearchResource.ashx?versionid=1668&type=1# |title=Archived copy |access-date=12 August 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130708145848/http://resources.knightfrank.com/GetResearchResource.ashx?versionid=1668&type=1# |archive-date=8 July 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ===Retail=== Kenya continues to experience some of the most decentralised growth of the retail market as marketers move outside Nairobi and go to other urban centres in Kenya such as Mombasa, Kisumu, Eldoret and Nakuru. ===Industrial=== Most industrial companies in Kenya tend to avoid renting or leasing space. However, over the recent years there has been significant development especially along Mombasa Rd. Rent and take up is low so the sector might need a couple more years to mature. ===Residential=== The residential market has actually been one of the key drivers of the property market. There has been a significant number of development projects coming up both within the Greater Nairobi Area and other urban areas such as Mombasa, Naivasha and Kisumu. ==Prime Global Cities Index== ===Q1 2013=== {| class="wikitable" |- | width="20px" style="background-color:#90EE90" | | Kenya |- | width="20px" style="background-color:#D0E7FF" | | Africa |} {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! America | data2 = 8.3 | label3 = Asia Pacific | data3 = 7.8 | label4 = Africa | data4 = 4.3 | label5 = Europe | data5 = -2.5 }} Source: [https://web.archive.org/web/20140309043640/http://resources.knightfrank.com/GetResearchResource.ashx?versionid=1773&type=1 KnightFrank] ==Greater Nairobi and Nairobi Metro== [[File:Nairobi metro within kenya.png|thumb|Nairobi Metro within [[Kenya]]]] Greater Nairobi consists of 4 out of 47 counties in Kenya but the area generates about 60% of the nation's wealth.http://196.200.27.243:8080/xmlui/bitstream/handle/123456789/111/Nairobi.pdf?sequence=3{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}http://www.nairobimetro.go.ke/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=43&Itemid=90{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. ====Upper Hill==== [[Upper Hill, Nairobi|Upper Hill]] has become an alternative for major companies seeking land cheaper than that which is in the Central Business District of Nairobi. It is one of the two main bases multinational firms consider when setting up in Kenya or Africa. Some of the firms include but are not limited to: [[Cisco Systems]], [[Citibank]], [[Coca-Cola]], [[Huawei]] and [[IMF]]. Average annual office rents for Grade A offices in Nairobi {| class="wikitable" |- | width="20px" style="background-color:#F5051c" | | Upper Hill |- | width="20px" style="background-color:#0000CD" | | Westlands |- | width="20px" style="background-color:#4CBB17" | | [[Nairobi#Central business district and skyline|Nairobi CBD]] |} {{Line chart | color_background = white | width = 400 | height = 200 | padding_left = 40 | padding_right = 15 | padding_top = 10 | padding_bottom = 20 | number_of_series = 3 | number_of_x-values = 5 | label_x1 = 2008 | label_x2 = 2009 | label_x3 = 2010 | label_x4 = 2011 | label_x5 = 2012 | y_max = 14 | scale = yes | interval_primary_scale = 2 | interval_secondary_scale = 1 | S01V01 = 7.9 | S01V02 = 8.9 | S01V03 = 10 | S01V04 = 10.5 | S01V05 = 12 | S02V01 = 7.9 | S02V02 = 10 | S02V03 = 11.1 | S02V04 = 12 | S02V05 = 12 | S03V01 = 5 | S03V02 = 5.9 | S03V03 = 6.3 | S03V04 = 7 | S03V05 = 7.9 | points = yes }} Source: [http://resources.knightfrank.com/GetResearchResource.ashx?versionid=1770&type=1 KnightFrank]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ====Westlands==== [[Westlands]] along with Upper Hill has become one of the two main bases for multinational firms that want to set up in Kenya or Africa. Some of the firms include but are not limited to: [[General Electric]], [[Google]] Africa headquarters, [[Intel Corporation]], [[LG]] and [[Standard Chartered|Standard Chartered Plc]]. {{wide image|Woodvale Grove, Westlands, Nairobi.jpg|800px|align-cap=center|Woodvale Grove, [[Westlands]]}} ====Gigiri==== Gigiri is home to Kenya's large [[expatriate]] community. It is one of the largest expat communities in Africa. It houses the [[United Nations Environmental Programme]]. [[Nairobi]] is the only African city to host a major UN body. It also has [[the Village Market]], which targets the expat community in Nairobi and hosts the [[International Civil Aviation Organization]] Base for Eastern and Southern Africa. Gigiri is considered one of Kenya's most posh suburbs along with [[Runda]] and [[Muthaiga]] which are really close to the place.{{cite web|url=http://www.hassconsult.co.ke/index.php/area-profile/area-profile/110-gigiri|title=HassConsult Real Estate|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2016}} It is comparable to the mostly-expat-inhabited neighbourhood of [[Itaewon]] in [[South Korea]]. However, it is much smaller. ====Runda, Muthaiga, Lavington, Karen==== These areas are Kenya's most expensive neighbourhoods; however, it is very likely that the neighbourhoods like Runda will lose its tag due to the recent demolitions{{cite web|url=http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/?articleID=2000084594&story_title=Kenya-anxiety-as-houses-in-runda-face-demolition|title=Anxiety as houses in Runda face demolition|first=Jeckonia|last=Otieno|work=Standard Digital News|accessdate=2 May 2016}} and others are seeing more and more townhouses rather than mansions and villas.http://allafrica.com/stories/201111250015.html ===Machakos (East Metro)=== [[File:Nairobi Metro location map.png|thumb|Nairobi Metro Map
[[Nairobi County]] (red)
[[Kajiado County]] (green)
[[Machakos County]] (yellow)
[[Kiambu County]] (purple)]] Towns in Machakos County on the outskirts of Nairobi from the 2000s been inhabited by people who work in Nairobi. [[Athi River]] is one town that has seen people move there. This shows that people have started to prefer living outside the core of the city. Under the Nairobi 2030 Masterplan, Machakos County is to become a dormitory town for Core Nairobi.http://www.nairobimetro.go.ke/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=25&Itemid=57{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|url=http://www.gizmag.com/konza-silicon-savanna/26033/|title=Kenya kickstarts multi-billion-dollar Konza Tech City|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2016}} ====Konza Techno City==== [[Konza Technology City]] dubbed "Africa’s Silicon Valley" will be the single largest property development ever done in Kenya. It is going to host the technology city as part of many programmes that aim to steer Kenya into middle income status. It will cost a whooping US$14.5 billion after commencing in January 2013 and is to be completed by 2030.http://techloy.com/2013/01/24/kenyas-president-launches-15-billion-konza-silicon-city-project/ ===Kiambu (North Metro)=== With the recent completion of the expansion of a road connecting Core Nairobi to Kiambu County, there has been a lot of property development happening with the most significant being: ====Tatu City==== Tatu City is a property development by [[Moscow]]-based Renaissance Partners. The development will cost US$2.5 billion; groundbreaking commenced in early 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.planetizen.com/node/62952|title=A Wave of 'New Cities' Are Poised to Transform Africa - For the Worse?|work=Planetizen: The Urban Planning, Design, and Development Network|accessdate=2 May 2016}} ===Kajiado (South Metro)=== [[Kajiado County]] is currently home to Kenya's richest people.{{cite web|url=http://www.nation.co.ke/News/politics/Kajiado-richest-county-Turkana-poorest-/-/1064/1930892/-/ain94qz/-/index.html|title=Kajiado richest county, Turkana poorest|date=29 July 2013|work=Daily Nation|accessdate=2 May 2016}} There are many residential neighbourhoods that host people who work in Nairobi examples are [[Ngong, Kenya|Ngong]], [[Kitengela]], [[Kiserian]] and [[Ongata Rongai]]. [[Kitengela]] is close to [[Athi River]] which has also started rising as a popular residential area. ==Mombasa== Mombasa is the second-largest city in [[Kenya]]. Prime land in Mombasa is up for grabs as a property boom like the one witnessed in the 1970s continues to push up home prices in the coastal town.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Investors-cash-in-on-Mombasa-land-rush-as-property-prices-soar/-/539546/1225096/-/bdka4yz/-/index.html|title=Investors cash in on Mombasa land rush as property prices soar|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2016}} ===Nyali=== [[Nyali]] houses some of the most expensive homes in Kenya. ===Shanzu=== Shanzu is also another affluent neighbourhood right past Whitesands beach hotel at Bamburi beach. The area houses high-profile housing developments. ===English Point Marina=== English Point Marina will be East and Central Africa's first floating pontoon marina. It will offer apartment living in the comfort, luxury and security of a hotel and will be managed by Pinewood Village Beach Resort. Units sold cost between KES. 36 and 150 million (US$410,000 – US$1.8 million).{{cite web|url=http://www.denisonyachtsales.com/2011/06/kenyas-first-marina-hopes-to-attract-boats-yachts/|title=Kenya's First Marina Hopes to Attract Boats & Yachts|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2016}} Despite the high prices, the units are almost sold out.{{When|date=February 2014}} The total cost of the project is about KES. 4.8 billion (US$60 million).http://www.megaprojects.co.ke/projects/20/details/#.UgDtcWQY1jA {{As of |March 2013}} the project was 30% complete.{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TfEdbA-IezY|title=English Point Marina 30% complete|date=17 May 2013|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2016|via=YouTube}} A complete virtual tour of the property has been created to give online users a feel of what to expect from the development.{{cite web|url=http://www.360tours.co.ke/tours/final/epm_tour|title=Marina EnglishPoint - 360 tours|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.nairobi.go.ke/ Nairobi City]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.mombasa.go.ke/ Mombasa City] * [http://www.tatucity.com/ Tatu City] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120309045311/http://www.konzacity.co.ke/ Konza City] {{Economy of Kenya}} {{Kenya topics}} {{Real estate}} [[Category:Economy of Kenya]] [[Category:Populated places in Kenya]] [[Category:Real estate by country|Kenya]]

{{distinguish|Rugby player (disambiguation){{!}}Rugby player}} {{more citations needed|date=August 2015}} [[File:Rugby-bottle.jpg|thumb|right|240px|A Rugby bottle.]] '''Rugby Boys''' are a collective term for [[Street gang|gangs]] of street children found in the [[Philippines]]. They are one of the most well-known [[poverty]]-afflicted people found in the slums of the Philippines. They are known for using and being addicted to a [[Adhesive#Contact adhesives|contact cement]] known as "Rugby" brand manufactured by [[Bostik]] and other aromatic solvents to alleviate their [[hunger]], and resulting in crime to fund their addiction.<ref name="torre">{{cite news|url=https://www.philstar.com/cebu-news/2009/05/18/468466/rugby-cheap-high-citys-street-kids-last-two-parts|title='Rugby': cheap high for city's street kids (Last of two parts)|author=AJ de la Torre, Niña G. Sumacot-Abenoja, Wenna Berondo|date=18 May 2009|work=[[The Philippine Star]]|accessdate=4 August 2018}}</ref>
Data from the Philippine [[Department of Social Welfare and Development]] show that the number of street children increased by 6,365 yearly, and half of the country’s street children, from 8 to 20 years old, have at one time sniffed Rugby and other inhalants. The relative ease of procuring these substances due to their low cost contributes to widespread abuse. There is no comprehensive epidemiologic data on the magnitude on inhalant abuse among children and adolescents in the Philippines. <ref name="wellsphere">{{cite web|url=http://www.wellsphere.com/men-s-health-article/quot-rugby-boys-quot/508771 |title= "Rugby boys" |publisher=Wellsphere.com |date=November 21, 2008 |accessdate=2012-04-08 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311062623/http://www.wellsphere.com/men-s-health-article/quot-rugby-boys-quot/508771 |archivedate=March 11, 2014}}</ref>
In response to widespread abuse of toluene-based substances, stricter rules have been imposed on the manufacture and sale of Rugby and similar glues by the Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency, such as the mandatory addition of [[mustard oil]] as a [[Bitterant|sniffing deterrent]]. In addition, purchasers will now be required to present valid identification for them to have access to contact cement that doesn't contain any bitterants or other such deterrents.<ref name="bitterant">{{cite news|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/nation/metro-manila/07/08/09/pdea-rugby-now-dangerous-drug|title=PDEA: Rugby now a 'prohibited drug'|work=[[ABS-CBNnews.com]]|publisher=[[ABS-CBN]]|accessdate=4 August 2018}}</ref>
==History== Wealthy [[adolescents]] were the first to use [[inhalants]] and become addicted to them, often using them to alleviate depression. In terms of [[Drug addiction|addiction]], inhalants are ordinary household products such as cleaners, cooking sprays, fabric protectors, paint thinner and adhesives and solvents. Because of the low cost of Rugby and other inhalants, poor people (especially inexperienced and destitute youths) use them to relieve hunger pangs and common poverty health problems.<ref>{{cite web|title='RUGBY BOY' JUMPS TO HIS DEATH FROM SCHOOLBUILDING|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1218827041.html|publisher=[[The Manila Times]] {{Subscription required|via=HighBeam}}|accessdate=4 August 2018|date=1 February 2007}}</ref> “Rugby Boys” (also called “Solvent Boys”) and even girls do the sniffing in the streets. The chemical is placed in a plastic bag, and inhaled from the bag to achieve euphoria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/rugby-boys-inhalant-abuse-philippines-94899.html?cat=62 |title= Yahoo Voices Rugby boys|publisher=Yahoo voice.com |date=October 26, 2006 |accessdate=2012-04-08 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140311075253/http://voices.yahoo.com/rugby-boys-inhalant-abuse-philippines-94899.html?cat=62 |archivedate = March 11, 2014}}</ref>
The impoverished population is the most common victim of addiction to dangerous and illegal substances. Once they are "high" they forget their hunger. Others become addicted because of family problems, poor self-esteem and [[peer pressure]]. Solvents, particularly Rugby, is the inhalant of choice in the Philippines for most teenagers since it is easily obtained. Less scrupulous store owners sell the adhesive in small portions to children and teenagers.
==Health problems== Inhalants cause nausea, blurred vision, memory lapse and loss of motor coordination. These effects may be a minor discomfort to the user after inhalation, but permanent damage from inhalants is irreversible. Damage to organs such as the [[liver]], [[kidneys]], [[brain]] and [[heart]] could be fatal.<ref name="torre"/>
A [[documentary]] by [[Karen Davila]] showed the effects of inhalant abuse on a person's body. One male teenager who served as the subject of the documentary has been addicted to Rugby for five years. He started sniffing Rugby due to [[Peer pressure|peer influence]]. His parents knew about his addiction, but as his mother explained, they were unable to dissuade him from inhaling the toxic substance. His father resorted to [[Corporal punishment in the home|beatings]] to teach him a lesson, to no avail. All his friends are addicts and the money they earn is saved to buy Rugby. The boy even turned his addiction into business, buying a bottle of Rugby then selling it in small portions to friends, and the profit enabled him to buy more Rugby.<ref name="wellsphere"/>
In the months they have observed this boy, they captured him at his lowest point. With the years of abuse that his body suffered, he could not stand or walk properly, and his body was scrawny. When he was taken for a medical exam, doctors found that he had [[tuberculosis]] and that his liver and kidneys were not functioning well. Through [[CT Scan]], it was found that his brain was smaller than average for his age bracket. Doctors said that if he continues his habit, he would either fall into a [[vegetative state]], in a [[coma]], or die.<ref name="torre"/>
The chemical [[toluene]] provides the aromatic smell of contact cement and other glue and is the culprit behind the addiction. Toluene abusers are exposed to levels above 1000 ppm (parts per million). Levels of exposure greater than 600 ppm cause confusion and delirium. Inhalant abuse causes permanent damage to the brain and may result in “sudden sniffing death”. It can also cause loss of memory, confusion or disorientation, distorted perception of time and distance, hallucinations, [[nausea]] and [[emesis]]. Inhalant abuse leads to muscle cramps and weakness, numbness of limbs, abdominal pains, damage to the central nervous system, kidneys and liver. It also produces psychological dependence. Once the habit is formed, the dose must be increased gradually to produce the same effect.<ref name="torre"/>
==Crimes attributed== Many Rugby boys have resorted to crime to fund their addiction. These crimes include [[robbery]], aggressive threats and hold-ups, [[drug trafficking]], and racketeering and small [[organized crimes]]. In a recent television documentary by Karen Davila, a Filipino broadcaster, a boy they ordered to buy Rugby from a store easily purchased a bottle of Rugby, and was told by the store owner that the Rugby should be wrapped in paper to conceal it. This is because there is a law prohibiting the selling of solvents to minors without parental consent. Many [[crime syndicates]] and common businessmen recruit and teach children how to get away with buying it.
Many of their crimes occur at crowded public places, when the police are distracted.
==See also== * [[Street children in the Philippines]]

[[File:RealStars trafficking model.jpg|thumb|The business model for sex trafficking as described by Swedish anti-sex work activists]] '''Sex trafficking''' is [[human trafficking]] for the purpose of sexual exploitation, including [[sexual slavery]].<ref name="Inside the Business of Modern Slavery">{{cite book|last1=Kara|first1=Siddharth |url=https://cup.columbia.edu/book/sex-trafficking/9780231139618 |title=Sex Trafficking: Inside the Business of Modern Slavery|date=2009|publisher=Columbia University Press |isbn=9780231139618 |accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref> Sex trafficking has two aspects of supply and demand. The sex exploitation is based on the interaction between the trafficker selling a victim (the individual being trafficked and sexually exploited) to customers to perform sexual services.<ref name="Global Social Welfare" /> Sex trafficking crimes are defined in three ways: acquisition, movement, and exploitation,<ref name="Inside the Business of Modern Slavery"/> and includes child sex tourism (CST), domestic minor sex trafficking (DMST) or commercial sexual exploitation of children, and prostitution.<ref name="Global Social Welfare" /> Sex trafficking is one of the biggest criminal businesses and is "the fastest growing criminal industry in the world." <ref>{{cite web|title=Anti-Trafficking|url=http://eternalthreads.org/product-category/red-thread-movement/|website=Eternal Threads|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref>
According to the [[International Labour Organization]], there are 20.9 million people subjected to forced labour, and 22% (4.5 million) who are victims of forced sexual exploitation.<ref name="OIT">{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---ed_norm/---declaration/documents/publication/wcms_181953.pdf|title=ILO 2012 Global estimate of forced labour - Executive summary|access-date=28 March 2015|format=PDF|publisher=International Labour Organization}}</ref> However, due to the covertness of sex trafficking, obtaining accurate, reliable statistics is difficult for researchers.<ref name="Tiefenbrun" /> The global commercial profits for sexual slavery are estimated to be $99B according to this same source.<ref>"Human Trafficking by the Numbers". (January 7,2017). [https://www.humanrightsfirst.org/resource/human-trafficking-numbers Human Rights First website] Retrieved 2 December 2018.</ref> In 2005, the figure was given as $9B for the total human trafficking industry.<ref>Daffron, Joshua W. (Dec 2011). "Combating Human Trafficking: Evolution of State Legislation and the Policies of the United Kingdom and France." Thesis, M.A. Monterey, Calif.:Department of National Security Affairs. Naval Postgraduate School. [https://apps.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a556270.pdf Defense Technical Information Center website] Retrieved 2 December 2018.</ref> <ref>Tiziana Luise. (2005). “Are human rights becoming burdensome for our economies? The role of slavery-like practices in the development of world economics and in the context of modern society,” Rivista Internazionale Di Scienze Sociali, 113(3): 473.</ref>
Most victims find themselves in coercive or abusive situations from which escape is both difficult and dangerous. Locations where this practice occurs span the globe and reflect an intricate web between nations, making it very difficult to construct viable solutions to this human rights problem.
==Defining the issue==
===Global=== In 2000, countries adopted a definition set forth by the [[United Nations]].<ref name="Villanova">{{cite journal|last1=Dempsey|first1=Michelle Madden|last2=Hoyle|first2=Carolyn|last3=Bosworth|first3=Mary|title=Defining Sex Trafficking in International and Domestic Law: Mind the Gaps|journal=Emory International Law Review|date=2012|volume=26|issue=1|series=Villanova Law/Public Policy Research Paper No. 2013-3036}}</ref> The United Nations Convention Against Transnational Organized Crime, [[Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, Especially Women and Children]], is also referred to as the Palermo Protocol. The Palermo Protocol created this definition.<ref name="Villanova"/> 147 of the 192 member states of the UN ratified the Palermo Protocol when it was published in 2000;<ref name="Villanova"/> as of September 2017, 171 states are parties.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=XVIII-12-a&chapter=18&lang=en%7Ctitle=UNTC%7Cwork=un.org%7Ctitle=UNTC%7Cwork=un.org|title=United Nations Treaty Collection|publisher=}}</ref> Article 3 of the Palermo Protocol states the definition as:<ref name="Palermo Protocol Doc">{{cite journal|last1=United Nations|title=Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, Especially Women and Children, Supplementing The United Nations Convention Against Transnational Organized Crime|date=2012|url=http://www.osce.org/odihr/19223?download=true|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
{{quote|(a) "Trafficking in persons" shall mean the recruitment, transportation, transfer, harbouring or receipt of persons, by means of the threat or use of force or other forms of coercion, of abduction, of fraud, of deception, of the abuse of power or of a position of vulnerability or of the giving or receiving of payments or benefits to achieve the consent of a person having control over another person, for the purpose of exploitation. Exploitation shall include, at a minimum, the exploitation of the prostitution of others or other forms of sexual exploitation, forced labour or services, slavery or practices similar to slavery, servitude or the removal of organs;
(b) The consent of a victim of trafficking in persons to the intended exploitation set forth in subparagraph (a) of this article shall be irrelevant where any of the means set forth in subparagraph (a) have been used;
(c) The recruitment, transportation, transfer, harbouring or receipt of a child for the purpose of exploitation shall be considered "trafficking in persons" even if this does not involve any of the means set forth in subparagraph (a) of this article;
(d) "Child" shall mean any person under eighteen years of age.}}
Article 5 of the Palermo Protocol then requires the member states to criminalize trafficking based on the definition outlined in Article 3; however, many member states' domestic laws reflect a narrower definition than Article 3.<ref name=Villanova /> Although these nations claim to be obliging Article 5, the narrow laws lead to a smaller portion of people being persecuted for sex trafficking.<ref name=Villanova />
The UN established various anti-trafficking tools, including a Global Report on Trafficking in Persons and an Inter-Agency Coordination Group Against Trafficking in Persons. The Global Report on Trafficking in Person provides new information based on data gathered from 155 countries. It offers first global assessment of the scope of [[human trafficking]] and what is being done to fight it. The UN General Assembly passed several resolutions on measuring to eliminate human trafficking. In 2010 the UN Global Plan of Action to Combat Trafficking in Persons was adopted. Various other organizations have engaged in global efforts against sex trafficking. "The UN Protocol's is the bedrock of the international initiatives against human sex trafficking" . The protocol includes several elements the first being: Action which includes recruitment,and transportation. The next element becomes a Means which includes coercion, fraud, or abuse of power towards others. The purpose element is the most concerning which can also be exploitation. This includes exploiting the prostitution, forced labor, slavery, and the removal of organs. The UN requires states and countries to establish the trafficking of humans as a criminal offense.
===United States=== After members of Prostitutes Anonymous who were survivors of modern domestic sex trafficking spent 13 years doing TV, radio, public appearances, news interviews, etc. and calling out that this country needed to "'do something' about it"{{snd}} an internationally recognized definition for sex trafficking was finally established with the Trafficking Act of 2000. It was during the same year the Palermo Protocol was enacted, the United States passed the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 (TVPA) to clarify the previous confusion and discrepancies in regards to the criminalizing guidelines of human trafficking.<ref name=Arizona>{{cite journal|last1=Lew|first1=Candace|title=Sex Trafficking of Domestic Minors in Phoenix, Arizona: A Research Project|date=July 2012|url=http://dianeandbrucehallefoundation.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/sex-trafficking-domestic-minors.pdf|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref> Through this act, sex trafficking crimes were defined as a situation where in which a "commercial sex act is induced by force, fraud, or coercion, or in which the person induced to perform such act has not attained 18 years of age."<ref name="TVPA Doc">{{cite web|last1=United States Government|title=Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000|url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/10492.pdf|website=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref> If the victim is a child under the age of 18 no force, fraud, or coercion needs to be proven based on this legislation.<ref name=Arizona /> Susan Tiefenbrun, a professor at the Thomas Jefferson School of Law who has written extensively on human trafficking, conducted research on the victims addressed in this act and discovered that each year more than two million women throughout the world are bought and sold for sexual exploitation.<ref name=Tiefenbrun>{{cite journal|last1=Tiefenbrun|first1=Susan|title=The Saga of Susannah A U.S. Remedy for Sex Trafficking in Women: The Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000|journal=Utah Law Review|date=2002|volume=107}}</ref> In order to clarify previous legal inconsistencies in regards to youth and trafficking, the United States took legal measures to define more varieties of exploitive situations in relation to children.<ref name=Arizona /> The two terms they defined and focused on were "commercial sexual exploitation of children" and "domestic minor sex trafficking." Commercial sexual exploitation of children (CSEC) is defined as "encompassing several forms of exploitation, including pornography, prostitution, child sex tourism, and child marriage."<ref name=Arizona /> Domestic minor sex trafficking (DMST) is a term that represents a subset of CSEC situations that have "the exchange of sex with a child under the age of 18, who is a United States (US) citizen or permanent resident, for a gain of cash, goods, or anything of value."<ref name=Arizona />
